author: Jamie Pandaram
title: Former Test captain Waugh to embark on 920km bike ride for charity
text:
HE stared down Curtly Ambrose, batted Australia out of deep trouble in the stinking Rawalpindi heat, and managed the ego of Shane Warne.
“But this is the toughest thing I’ve ever done,” Steve Waugh says.
He’s talking about a bike ride. All 920km over six days, from Sydney to Byron Bay, starting Sunday, to raise money for children and young adults suffering from rare diseases.

“With cricket, I knew what I was doing, but this is completely out of my comfort zone, I honestly don’t know whether I will finish this,” Waugh says.
For a man renowned as the toughest player to have pulled on a baggy green cap, Waugh’s summation of his looming challenge speaks volumes.
Steve Waugh will ride 920km for charity. Picture. Phil Hillyard Source: News Corp Australia
“I’ll line up Sunday morning and hope I’ll make it to the end, but I’m still not 100 per cent sure,’ he says.
“I know it’s a tough ride, the group who are organising it on tour have said this is the hardest ride they’ve ever designed.
“It mentally challenges me in the same way as when I played cricket for Australia, except I knew what I was doing when I was playing cricket.
HELP SUPPORT THE STEVE WAUGH FOUNDATION HERE
“This is more of a mental challenge. Because it’s just you on the bike, there’s a lot of times I feel as if I have to stop now, it’s too hard, I’m going to pull off, but you find a way to get through it.
“I’m trying to use the motivation of all our kids, who show amazing strength and character with everything they do every day, and I’m thinking I can’t pull out, I can’t take a short cut, the kids wouldn’t do that so I can’t do it.”
Steve Waugh stares down Curtly Ambrose. Source: News Limited
The Steve Waugh Foundation marks its 10th anniversary of helping young sufferers of rare diseases this year and Waugh was looking to mark the occasion in typically challenging fashion.
He wants to raise more than $600,000 for the youngsters his foundation helps — some whose diseases are so rare they are the only sufferers of it in Australia — and knew that to do so he’d need to come up with an out-of-the-box idea.
Waugh had never seriously cycled until four months ago, but after a friend of his completed the Sydney-Byron ride after a quadruple heart by-pass, the former Australian skipper decided it was the event that could capture the public’s interest.
He’s gathered 60 riders to make the trip including celebrities Mick Doohan, John Maclean, pro-cyclist Simon Gerrans and Dr Charlie Teo.
They’ll cover approximately 150km a day across the NSW countryside, through the Hunter Valley, Gloucester, Armidale, Dorrigo and Grafton, before arriving into Byron Bay on Friday, November 6.
“The rare disease patient is the orphan of the health system, often without diagnosis, without treatment, without research and therefore without reason to hope,” Waugh said.
“This is why the Steve Waugh Foundation exists. The Australian rare disease community is growing, with a leading number of medical and advocacy groups joining together to give those living with a rare disease a voice.”
To read individual stories about the children the Waugh Foundation is helping and to make a donation towards Waugh’s efforts, visit www.stevewaughfoundation.com.au
